title: 2 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who was Sheba, the man who blew the trumpet and declared 'We have no part in David'?
questions.correctAnswer: Son of Bichri, a Benjamite
questions.explanation: Sheba was identified as the son of Bichri, a Benjamite, who blew the trumpet and declared rebellion against David (2 Samuel 20:1).

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 20:2, which group remained loyal to King David?
questions.correctAnswer: The men of Judah
questions.explanation: The men of Judah clung to King David from Jordan to Jerusalem, while the men of Israel followed Sheba (2 Samuel 20:2).

questions.question: What did King David do to the ten concubines he had left in Jerusalem?
options: Put them in ward and fed them but did not go in to them
questions.correctAnswer: Put them in ward and fed them but did not go in to them
questions.explanation: David took the ten concubines, put them in ward, fed them, but did not have relations with them, and they lived in widowhood until death (2 Samuel 20:3).

questions.question: Who did King David command to assemble the men of Judah within three days?
questions.correctAnswer: Amasa
questions.explanation: David told Amasa to assemble the men of Judah within three days and be present (2 Samuel 20:4).

questions.question: True or False: Amasa assembled the men of Judah on time as King David commanded.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amasa delayed assembling the men of Judah beyond the time appointed by David (2 Samuel 20:5).

questions.question: Who did David instruct to pursue Sheba to prevent him from escaping to fortified cities?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: David told Abishai to pursue Sheba lest he escape to fortified cities (2 Samuel 20:6).

questions.question: Which groups of men went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba?
options: Joab's men, Cherethites, Pelethites, and mighty men
questions.correctAnswer: Joab's men, Cherethites, Pelethites, and mighty men
questions.explanation: Joab's men, Cherethites, Pelethites, and all mighty men went out to pursue Sheba (2 Samuel 20:7).

questions.question: What happened to Joab's garment as he went before the men at Gibeon?
options: A sword fastened to his girdle fell out
It was torn by a thorn
questions.correctAnswer: A sword fastened to his girdle fell out
questions.explanation: As Joab went forth, the sword fastened to his girdle fell out (2 Samuel 20:8).

questions.question: How did Joab kill Amasa?
options: By stabbing him in the fifth rib with a sword
By striking him with a club
By throwing him from a cliff
questions.correctAnswer: By stabbing him in the fifth rib with a sword
questions.explanation: Joab stabbed Amasa in the fifth rib with a sword, causing his death (2 Samuel 20:10).

questions.question: True or False: After killing Amasa, Joab immediately stopped pursuing Sheba.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: After killing Amasa, Joab and Abishai continued to pursue Sheba (2 Samuel 20:10).

questions.question: What did one of Joab's men say to those who favored Joab and David?
questions.correctAnswer: Let him go after Joab
questions.explanation: One of Joab's men said, 'He that favoureth Joab, and he that is for David, let him go after Joab' (2 Samuel 20:11).

questions.question: Where did Sheba flee to after gathering followers from the tribes of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Abel of Bethmaachah
questions.explanation: Sheba fled to Abel of Bethmaachah where he was besieged (2 Samuel 20:14-15).

questions.question: What did the wise woman of Abel say Joab was seeking to do?
options: Destroy a city and a mother in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy a city and a mother in Israel
questions.explanation: The wise woman said Joab sought to destroy a city and mother in Israel (2 Samuel 20:19).

questions.question: True or False: Joab denied wanting to destroy the city of Abel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joab said it was far from him to destroy or swallow up the city (2 Samuel 20:20).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The woman said to Joab, 'Behold, his ______ shall be thrown to thee over the wall.'
questions.correctAnswer: head
questions.explanation: The woman promised Joab Sheba's head would be thrown to him over the wall (2 Samuel 20:21).

questions.question: Who was over the Cherethites and Pelethites according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites (2 Samuel 20:23).

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling abandoned and questions their inheritance in Christ. Based on 2 Samuel 20, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's plan?
options: God remains faithful even when others turn away
One should rely solely on their own strength
Inheritance is earned by fighting others
Leaving the community is the best solution
questions.correctAnswer: God remains faithful even when others turn away
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 20:1-2, Sheba declares no part in David, yet the men of Judah remain loyal, showing God's faithfulness through David's leadership despite division. This teaches us to trust God's plan even when others falter.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 20 teach about the importance of obedience and prompt action in serving God and community?
options: Obedience requires timely action as shown by Amasa’s delay
Delays in service have no consequences
Leaders should act only when convenient
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience requires timely action as shown by Amasa’s delay
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:4-5 shows David instructing Amasa to assemble men in three days, but Amasa delays. This illustrates the need for prompt obedience and responsibility in serving God's purposes.

questions.question: A believer struggles with forgiveness after betrayal. What example from 2 Samuel 20 can help them understand God’s grace in difficult relationships?
options: David's treatment of his concubines shows restraint despite betrayal
Revenge is the best response to betrayal
questions.correctAnswer: David's treatment of his concubines shows restraint despite betrayal
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 20:3, David puts his concubines in custody but does not approach them again, showing a sober, restrained response to personal betrayal instead of harsh punishment or revenge.

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 20 teach about the danger of rebellion against godly leadership and how to respond?
options: Rebellion leads to division and must be confronted wisely
Rebellion is acceptable if one disagrees with leadership
Rebellion is a sign of spiritual maturity
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion leads to division and must be confronted wisely
questions.explanation: Sheba’s rebellion in 2 Samuel 20:1-7 causes division, but David and Joab pursue him to preserve peace. This shows the need to address rebellion carefully to protect unity and righteousness.

questions.question: A believer asks about humility in leadership. What does Joab’s interaction with Amasa in 2 Samuel 20 reveal about handling rivalry and ambition?
options: Unaddressed ambition can lead to violent outcomes
Rivalry should be ignored and tolerated
Leaders should openly compete to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: Unaddressed ambition can lead to violent outcomes
questions.explanation: Joab kills Amasa in 2 Samuel 20:8-10, showing that rivalry and unchecked ambition can cause harm. This warns believers to pursue humility and peace in leadership.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 20 illustrate the value of wise counsel and peacemaking within the church community?
options: The wise woman’s intervention brings peace and prevents destruction
Silence is better than counsel during conflict
Conflict should be resolved by force only
questions.correctAnswer: The wise woman’s intervention brings peace and prevents destruction
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 20:16-22, a wise woman negotiates with Joab to save her city, demonstrating the power of wise counsel and peacemaking in preserving community and life.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with perseverance during trials. What lesson from Joab’s pursuit of Sheba can encourage them?
options: Persistent pursuit of righteousness leads to victory
Giving up quickly is wise in hard times
Avoid confronting problems to prevent conflict
Trials are a reason to isolate oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent pursuit of righteousness leads to victory
questions.explanation: Joab and his men relentlessly pursue Sheba (2 Samuel 20:6-7, 13-15), showing that perseverance in doing what is right brings resolution and peace.

questions.question: What does the treatment of David’s concubines in 2 Samuel 20 teach about integrity and responsibility in family life?
options: Even in difficult circumstances, responsibility and provision must continue
Family responsibilities can be neglected without consequences
Family life is secondary to political matters
questions.correctAnswer: Even in difficult circumstances, responsibility and provision must continue
questions.explanation: David feeds and cares for his concubines even though he does not approach them again (2 Samuel 20:3), demonstrating responsible care and integrity in family relationships despite hardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 20, Joab’s leadership role was uncontested and peaceful throughout the chapter.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joab kills Amasa to maintain command (2 Samuel 20:8-10), indicating his leadership was contested and involved conflict.

questions.question: True or False: The wise woman in Abel acted as a peacemaker to protect her community, showing the importance of wisdom and diplomacy in conflict resolution.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The wise woman negotiates with Joab to prevent destruction in 2 Samuel 20:16-22, exemplifying godly wisdom and peacemaking.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joab was over all the host of Israel, and _____ the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites.
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:23 states that Joab was over all the host, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 20 encourage believers to handle conflicts within the church body?
options: Seek peaceful solutions through wise counsel and avoid unnecessary violence
Ignore conflicts until they resolve themselves
Use force immediately to suppress dissent
Withdraw from the community to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Seek peaceful solutions through wise counsel and avoid unnecessary violence
questions.explanation: The wise woman’s negotiation in 2 Samuel 20:16-22 prevented destruction, emphasizing the importance of peace and wisdom in resolving conflicts.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity in leadership can be learned from Joab’s actions in 2 Samuel 20?
options: Leadership must be exercised with humility to avoid harmful rivalry
Using violence is the best way to maintain authority
questions.correctAnswer: Leadership must be exercised with humility to avoid harmful rivalry
questions.explanation: Joab’s killing of Amasa (2 Samuel 20:8-10) shows the dangers of pride and rivalry, teaching leaders to lead humbly and peacefully.

questions.question: A believer is confused about how to stay faithful during opposition. What example from David’s experience in 2 Samuel 20 can guide them?
options: Remain loyal to God’s anointed despite division and threats
Avoid difficult situations by separating from the community
Fight for personal gain at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Remain loyal to God’s anointed despite division and threats
questions.explanation: Despite Sheba’s rebellion (2 Samuel 20:1-2), David retains the loyalty of Judah and trusts God’s plan, showing faithfulness amid trials.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 20 teach about stewardship and responsibility in leadership roles?
options: Leaders must act responsibly and protect the community’s welfare
Leaders can neglect their duties without consequences
Leadership is primarily about personal power
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must act responsibly and protect the community’s welfare
questions.explanation: David’s instructions to Amasa (2 Samuel 20:4-5) and Joab’s pursuit of Sheba (2 Samuel 20:6-7) show responsible leadership focused on community protection.

questions.question: What does the resolution of Sheba’s rebellion in 2 Samuel 20 teach about repentance and reconciliation in the body of Christ?
options: Rebellion must be confronted but can end in restoration of peace
Violence is the only solution to conflict
Rebellions are to be ignored for peace
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion must be confronted but can end in restoration of peace
questions.explanation: Sheba is dealt with decisively (2 Samuel 20:21-22), and peace is restored with leaders returning to the king, showing that confronting sin leads to communal peace.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who was the man that incited rebellion against King David by blowing a trumpet and declaring 'We have no part in David'?
questions.correctAnswer: Sheba, the son of Bichri
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:1 identifies Sheba, the son of Bichri, as the man who blew a trumpet and incited rebellion against David.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the tribes of Israel to Sheba's rebellion in contrast to the tribe of Judah?
options: Israel followed Sheba; Judah remained loyal to David
Israel remained loyal; Judah followed Sheba
Both Israel and Judah followed Sheba
Both Israel and Judah remained loyal to David
questions.correctAnswer: Israel followed Sheba; Judah remained loyal to David
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:2 shows that all Israel followed Sheba, but Judah clung to King David from Jordan to Jerusalem.

questions.question: What did King David do with his ten concubines during the rebellion?
options: Put them in ward and fed them but did not lie with them
Sent them away for their safety
Kept them with him in the palace
Allowed them to leave and join Sheba
questions.correctAnswer: Put them in ward and fed them but did not lie with them
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 20:3, David put the ten concubines in ward, fed them, but did not have relations with them, effectively placing them in widowhood.

questions.question: Who did David command to assemble the men of Judah within three days?
questions.correctAnswer: Amasa
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:4 shows David instructed Amasa to assemble the men of Judah within three days.

questions.question: What was Amasa's failure after being sent to gather the men of Judah?
options: He delayed longer than the appointed time
He gathered men from the wrong tribes
He betrayed David by joining Sheba
He was killed before completing the task
questions.correctAnswer: He delayed longer than the appointed time
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:5 states that Amasa tarried longer than the set time appointed by David.

questions.question: What foreshadowing event occurs involving Joab and Amasa during the pursuit of Sheba?
options: Joab kills Amasa by stabbing him
Amasa kills Joab by surprise attack
questions.correctAnswer: Joab kills Amasa by stabbing him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:10 narrates how Joab stabbed Amasa fatally, an event that foreshadows the brutality and political intrigue in David’s reign.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the interaction where Joab greets Amasa by taking him by the beard before killing him?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The greeting by taking Amasa by the beard to kiss him (2 Samuel 20:9) is deeply ironic since Joab quickly kills him, highlighting betrayal.

questions.question: After killing Amasa, what signal does one of Joab's men give to those who favor Joab and David?
options: He tells them to follow Joab
He blows a trumpet for retreat
He commands a siege of Abel
He signals to divide the army
questions.correctAnswer: He tells them to follow Joab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:11 states that one of Joab’s men told those favoring Joab and David to go after Joab for the pursuit of Sheba.

questions.question: Where did Sheba find refuge leading to a siege by Joab’s forces?
questions.correctAnswer: Abel of Bethmaachah
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:15 describes how Sheba was besieged in Abel of Bethmaachah.

questions.question: What role does the wise woman of Abel play in the resolution of the siege?
options: She negotiates peace and arranges Sheba's execution
She leads the defense against Joab
She convinces Joab to withdraw without a fight
questions.correctAnswer: She negotiates peace and arranges Sheba's execution
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 20:16-22, the wise woman requests to speak with Joab and arranges for Sheba's head to be thrown over the wall, ending the siege.

questions.question: Which theme is prominently developed in this chapter through the rebellion and its suppression?
questions.correctAnswer: Loyalty to the Davidic monarchy
questions.explanation: The rebellion by Sheba and Judah’s loyalty to David (2 Samuel 20:2) highlight the theme of loyalty to the Davidic throne which is a key theological and political theme in Scripture.

questions.question: What is the significance of Joab blowing a trumpet after Sheba's head was thrown over the wall?
options: It signals the end of the rebellion and retreat
It warns of an incoming attack
questions.correctAnswer: It signals the end of the rebellion and retreat
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 20:22, Joab’s trumpet blast signals the retreat of his forces and the end of Sheba’s revolt.

questions.question: Who was appointed over the Cherethites and Pelethites during David’s reign as mentioned at the end of the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:23 states that Benaiah was over the Cherethites and Pelethites.

questions.question: True or False: The woman in Abel claimed that the city was known as a place where disputes were settled peacefully in old times.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:18 records the woman saying that in old times, people used to ask counsel at Abel to end disputes peacefully.

questions.question: What was the cultural significance of Joab taking Amasa by the beard before killing him?
options: It was a traditional greeting symbolizing brotherhood
It was a ritual to curse the opponent
It was a sign of surrender
It represented a formal challenge to duel
questions.correctAnswer: It was a traditional greeting symbolizing brotherhood
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern culture, taking someone by the beard to kiss was a sign of brotherhood or friendship, making Joab’s act of killing Amasa deeply treacherous (2 Samuel 20:9).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who was Sheba, and what was his declaration against David as recorded in 2 Samuel 20?
options: A man of Belial who claimed no part in David and called Israel to separate from him
A faithful servant of David who defended his kingship
A prophet who warned David of coming judgment
A priest who mediated peace between Israel and Judah
questions.correctAnswer: A man of Belial who claimed no part in David and called Israel to separate from him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:1 describes Sheba as a man of Belial who blew a trumpet and declared that Israel had no part in David, urging them to separate. This reflects the biblical theme of rebellion against God's anointed (1 Samuel 15:23, Psalm 2:2, Acts 5:29, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the tribes of Israel and Judah to Sheba's rebellion?
options: Israel followed Sheba, but Judah remained loyal to David
Both Israel and Judah united to follow Sheba
Judah followed Sheba, but Israel remained loyal to David
Both Israel and Judah abandoned David
questions.correctAnswer: Israel followed Sheba, but Judah remained loyal to David
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:2 states that the men of Israel went after Sheba, but the men of Judah cleaved to their king, David. This division highlights the theme of loyalty to God's chosen leader (Genesis 49:10, Deuteronomy 17:15, Psalm 89:20-37, John 19:19-22).

questions.question: What action did King David take concerning his concubines during this crisis?
options: He put them under guard and fed them but did not have relations with them
He sent them away for their safety
He allowed them to support the army
He took them with him on the battlefield
questions.correctAnswer: He put them under guard and fed them but did not have relations with them
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:3 recounts that David put his ten concubines in ward, fed them, but did not go in to them, showing the seriousness of the crisis and the symbolic mourning of the king. This illustrates the biblical principle of purity and consecration in times of judgment (Leviticus 15:19, 2 Samuel 12:20, Ezekiel 16:8, Hebrews 13:4).

questions.question: What command did David give to Amasa, and what was the result?
options: Assemble the men of Judah in three days, but Amasa delayed
Pursue Sheba immediately, and Amasa obeyed quickly
Negotiate with Sheba, and Amasa succeeded
Stay in Jerusalem and defend the city, and Amasa complied
questions.correctAnswer: Assemble the men of Judah in three days, but Amasa delayed
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:4-5 records David's command to Amasa to assemble Judah's men within three days, but Amasa tarried longer than appointed. This delay contrasts with faithful obedience and shows the consequences of hesitation in God's service (Exodus 32:26, Judges 2:11-15, 1 Samuel 15:22, Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: Who did David instruct to pursue Sheba and why?
options: Abishai and Joab's men, to prevent Sheba from escaping
The priests, to pray for deliverance
The elders of Israel, to lead a rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai and Joab's men, to prevent Sheba from escaping
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:6-7 shows David telling Abishai to pursue Sheba with Joab's men to prevent him from fortifying cities and escaping, emphasizing God's justice and protection of His anointed (Psalm 18:39, 2 Kings 19:32-34, Romans 12:19, Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: What significant event happened between Joab and Amasa during the pursuit of Sheba?
options: Joab killed Amasa by stabbing him
questions.correctAnswer: Joab killed Amasa by stabbing him
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:8-10 records Joab killing Amasa by stabbing him in the ribs, an act of betrayal despite a greeting of peace. This reflects the biblical reality of human sinfulness and the consequences of ambition and violence (Genesis 4:8, Judges 9:24, Matthew 26:48-50, James 4:1).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people after Amasa was killed?
options: They followed Joab to continue the pursuit of Sheba
They mourned Amasa and refused to fight
They sided with Sheba against Joab
They dispersed and abandoned the conflict
questions.correctAnswer: They followed Joab to continue the pursuit of Sheba
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:11-13 describes how, after Amasa was removed from the highway, the people followed Joab to pursue Sheba, illustrating the theme of loyalty to God's appointed leaders and the continuation of justice (Joshua 1:14-15, 1 Samuel 22:2, Hebrews 13:17, Romans 13:4).

questions.question: Where did Sheba take refuge, and what was the military response?
options: Abel of Bethmaachah; the city was besieged and its walls battered
Hebron; a peace treaty was made
questions.correctAnswer: Abel of Bethmaachah; the city was besieged and its walls battered
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:14-15 shows Sheba taking refuge in Abel of Bethmaachah, where Joab's forces besieged the city and battered its walls, exemplifying God's justice against rebellion (Joshua 6:1-5, 2 Kings 19:35-37, Nehemiah 4:17-18, Revelation 20:9).

questions.question: Who spoke to Joab from the city, and what was her message?
options: A wise woman who urged peace and resolution to avoid destruction
A prophetess declaring judgment on Joab
questions.correctAnswer: A wise woman who urged peace and resolution to avoid destruction
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:16-19 records a wise woman from the city who spoke to Joab, urging him not to destroy the city and to seek peace, reflecting biblical wisdom traditions and the value of peace (Proverbs 31:26, Ecclesiastes 7:5, Matthew 5:9, James 3:17).

questions.question: How did Joab respond to the wise woman's plea?
options: He assured her he did not intend to destroy the city but sought Sheba's head
He ignored her and continued the siege
He agreed to negotiate with Sheba
questions.correctAnswer: He assured her he did not intend to destroy the city but sought Sheba's head
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:20-21 records Joab's response that he did not want to destroy the city but was after Sheba, the rebel, emphasizing God's justice and the protection of His inheritance (Psalm 11:5, Isaiah 1:17, Romans 13:4, Revelation 19:2).

questions.question: What was the outcome after the wise woman acted among the people of the city?
options: They beheaded Sheba and threw his head to Joab
They opened the gates to Sheba
They continued the siege for another month
questions.correctAnswer: They beheaded Sheba and threw his head to Joab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:22 shows the people, through the wise woman's counsel, cut off Sheba's head and cast it out to Joab, demonstrating the triumph of God's justice and the end of rebellion (Psalm 37:28, Proverbs 16:4, Acts 5:38-39, Revelation 20:10).

questions.question: Who was appointed over all the army of Israel after these events?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:23 identifies Joab as over all the host of Israel, signifying his role in God's providence over the king's army, reflecting God's sovereignty in raising leaders (Exodus 17:9-13, 1 Samuel 17:55-58, 2 Kings 18:17, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: Who was over the Cherethites and Pelethites according to the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:23 states that Benaiah was over the Cherethites and Pelethites, showing the organization of David's forces under God’s providential authority (1 Chronicles 11:22, Psalm 18:34, 2 Samuel 8:18, Hebrews 11:34).

questions.question: What duties did Adoram and Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud hold?
options: Adoram was over the tribute, Jehoshaphat was recorder
Adoram was a priest, Jehoshaphat was a scribe
Adoram was a prophet, Jehoshaphat a judge
questions.correctAnswer: Adoram was over the tribute, Jehoshaphat was recorder
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:24 details that Adoram was over the tribute and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder, illustrating the administration of God's kingdom through faithful servants (Exodus 30:11-16, 1 Chronicles 29:1-5, Romans 13:6-7, Hebrews 13:7).

questions.question: Who were the priests mentioned in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Zadok and Abiathar
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:25 names Zadok and Abiathar as the priests, emphasizing the continuity of God's covenantal priesthood and the spiritual leadership under David (Exodus 28:1, 1 Samuel 2:35, Hebrews 7:23-28, Psalm 110:4).

questions.question: What role did Ira the Jairite serve according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: A chief ruler about David
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 20:26 mentions Ira the Jairite as a chief ruler about David, reflecting God's provision of wise and godly leadership in the administration of His kingdom (1 Chronicles 27:32, Nehemiah 5:14, Romans 13:1-4, Titus 1:7).
